messages.text: (X-Post from <#C767M3VB3|academia>) I was suggested by <@U8JP5B9T2> to post this question here. Any insight? Thanks!

attachments.fallback: [January 4th, 2021 1:26 PM] jacobszelko: Hey is anyone here part of OHDSI (Observational Health Data Sciences and Informatics)? I see that there are no software packages built in Julia for the interface - I am trying to figure out if that is by choice or if there is simply a paucity of Julia programmers in this space. Thanks! :juliaheartpulse-dark:
attachments.text: Hey is anyone here part of OHDSI (Observational Health Data Sciences and Informatics)? elements.text: to post this question here. Any insight? Thanks!

messages.text: I want to say <@ULTB7E6UW> has/was planning to do something. The posts in question are all :slack-on-fire: now though

elements.text: has/was planning to do something. The posts in question are all

messages.text: <@US64J0NPQ> Hi.  So, about 18 months ago we produced a prototype adapter to OHDSI using DataKnots (<https://querycombinators.org/dist/ohdsiknots-20190816.pdf>) with implementation <https://github.com/rbt-lang/SynPUF-HCFU>. We presented this at OHDSI's conference in 2019, <https://www.ohdsi.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/ohdsi-201909116.jpg> -- Anyway, this work is a lovely prototype, but not practical.  At this time, we're working on the SQL translation part of the challenge (<https://github.com/rbt-lang/DataKnots4Postgres.jl/tree/execute-shape>).  Probably this will be ~9 months before it's working, as we're making reasonable progress now.  Once that's done, we should be able to write OHDSI queries using DataKnots.

messages.text: <@US64J0NPQ> Anyway, if you have any particular requirements or timelines, let me know.  Sometimes it's more fun to build things when there are some practical constraints. I'm more often on Zulip.
